Title#1: Request for damage backing
Abstract#1: Event funding requests to the Cultural Events Board for the Cinco de Mayo celebration (1972), MAYA conference fundraising, music marathon (1971), benefit dance for Pakastani refugees (November, 1971), and the Ballet Chicano (September, 1971). Document mostly consists of funding request forms with little detail of the events. It also includes a request to the Cultural Events Board for damage backing regarding the Herbie Mann concert (March, 1972). There is also a standard request form with little information. (Cancelation of this concert is refered to in the Gary Archuleta letter re: the founding of U-LET-US-UNLIMITED - 1973-03-15; record identifier: narv_chicanxHistory_CEB_Correspondence_71-72_001.pdf).

Title#1: Press release regarding the prevention of a talk by Representative Henry B. Gonzales
Abstract#1: Press release describing 200 demonstrators "mostly Chicanos believed.. to be from outside the Boulder area," who interrupted a speech by U.S. congressman Henry Gonzales, as part of the University Summer Lecture series in the UMC ballroom. Gonzales had met with members of UMAS before his speech. "The protest.. centered around.. Gozalez' conservative stand on issues affecting Chicanos..." They called him a "sell-out." There was property damage but no arrests.

Title#1: Letter from Patrick Vigil to Abraham Flexer
Abstract#1: Letter to Dr. Flexer in the Biology department. Vigil thanks Flexer for support of the UMAS summer program. He reiterates the need for the program as he states "This program developed by your graduate students, and with full support from your Department faculty, shows innovative promise to afford the opportunity, and provide the methods which will spark the dormant and untapped biological science intrests and abilities of our students." He continues to mention that most of the students in the program are labled "'high-risk' because of low high school grade point averages and various socio-economic factors, we truly believe that their scholastic deficiencies are the result of many complex cultural and environmental circumstances, rather than any innate inaptitude." He also tells the story of an anonymous Mexican American student from 1955 who only stayed at CU for one semester, when there were only 7 Mexican American students enrolled.
Subject Name#3: University of Colorado, Boulder. Educational Opportunity Program

Title#1: Educational Opportunities Program for Mexican-Americans: Introduction and objectives
Abstract#1: Report titled, "Educational Opportunities Program for Mexican-Americans, Introduction and Objectives." The report talks about the integration of the summer program and states, "Since the Mexican-American value system conflicts with the dominant white culture, the process or road to acculteration for Mexican-American youth is an impossible or at best a difficult task. The methods for dealing with the problems inherent with this culture conflict will be the organically integrated approach. The integration of the Program shall be achieved by structuring most of the student course work and related activites around the sociological concept of the role model emulation and the Mexican-American cultural pattern of the positive reinforcement values gained through the cohesiveness of the family." The report continues to talk about the "family feeling" coming from staff members of the University.
Subject Name#1: University of Colorado, Boulder. Educational Opportunity Program

Title#1: 1973 EOP budget requests vs. suggested planning parameters
Abstract#1: Memo; re: "1973 EOP Budget Requests vs. Suggested Planning Parameters." Outlines funds requested by UMAS (as well as BEP, MAP, "Asians," and "Indians"). The document shows how requests exceeded budgeted expectations for instruction support, tutoring, non-instructional programs, and adminsitration. UMAS estimated 300 enrollment in the summer, though Student Affairs expected 200. UMAS requests funding for addtional course offerings, academic advisors, grad students, and social events.

Title#1: Immediate recruitment and solutions to problems related to Office of Admissions
Abstract#1: Memos to Dean Volsky and others regarding recruitment from May, 1970-November, 1970 from Becky Marrujo, Patrick Vigil, Andres Gavaldon and other UMAS officials. It describes historic issues with UMAS recruitment. Asserts that UMAS students are best at recruiting other students. They make recommendations for improvements and specifically reject recruitment programs developed without input from Mexican American students.

Title#1: Policy statement on EOP organizational structure (Boulder campus)
Abstract#1: Policy Statement on EOP Organzational Structure (Boulder Campus). Recommendations to better support EOP programs, with the Faculty Board administering. There are hand written notes at the bottom. One note states for example, "This is a reestablishing of what the program was developed to [oppose?]. This is a replica of what the univ. was - The only difference is that the faculty wants to instead of the administration. It is a coup d'etat. - 2. Faculty wants to control through a puppet." As well as, "Total distrust of Minority People with the exception of minority faculty members...."
